Metadata: Aristotle revisited: the function of pyloric caeca in fish
"Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences," 83:8012-8014, October 1986.

The function of the pyloric caeca of fish has been uncertain since their description by Aristotle. He suggested three hypotheses about their function: storage, fermentation, and digestion. The authors' results for trout, cod, largemouth bass, and striped bass support the third but not the first or second of Aristotle's theories. In all four species, the caeca prove to be a major site of sugar, amino acid, and dipeptide uptake, contributing more uptake than the entire remaining alimentary tract in trout and cod. Caecal brush-border membranes contain hydrolytic enzymes. Caeca fill and empty with the same time course as proximal intestine. Whereas the caeca of mammals and birds serve as fermentation chambers, fish caeca are an adaptation to increase gut surface area.
